questions.text: A 45-year-old man complaining of pain in the right flank has been diagnosed with right-sided renal calculi measuring 2.2cm. Urine microscopy finding is shown in the image. What is the most suitable treatment among the following in this patient?

choices.text: No treatment required just pain management suffices

questions.solution:
The image of the urine microscopy shows hexagonal shaped cystine stone. Hence the best suitable treatment in a patient with right-sided cysteine renal calculi measuring 2.2 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Cysteine stone is relatively resistant to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy and a stone size of more than 2 cm necessitates percutaneous nephrolithotomy. ECWL is done until the renal stone size of less than 1.5cm.

PCNL is indicated in the following condition:

  • If the patient has anatomical obstruction like pelviureteric obstruction, calyceal diverticula, distal ureteral obstruction.
  • Hard renal stones like cystine stone, calcium oxalate stone.
  • If the renal stone is struvite stone as it is associated with urinary tract infection.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

  • Cystine stones: Hexagonal
  • Uric acid stones: Varying shapes (rhomboids or parallelograms)
  • Calcium oxalate
    • Monohydrate: Dumbbell shaped
    • Dihydrate: Octahedral or envelope shaped
  • Struvite stones: Rectangular or coffin lid

questions.text: A patient presents with photophobia and blurring of vision. On examination, the eye appears as shown below.  What is the mainstay of treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of photophobia and blurring of vision along with red-eye and irregularly shaped pupil (image) suggest a diagnosis of uveitis. Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of the treatment of uveitis.

Steroids are the drug of choice in anterior uveitis. They reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect. 

Cycloplegics like 1% atropine, relieve spasm of the iris sphincter and ciliary muscles. They prevent the formation of synechiae and reduce exudation.

Systemic therapy includes steroids, NSAIDs, and immunosuppressants. 

Immunosuppressants like voclosporin (calcineurin inhibitor), are used in severe cases. They are being studied under a program called LUMINATE.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the GFR?

choices.text: Decrease in bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.solution:
A decrease in Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

A decrease in Bowman's Capsule Hydrostatic Pressure increases GFR because it reduces the opposing force to filtration, thus enhancing the net filtration pressure and increasing the amount of filtrate formed.

Factors that can increase the GFR are as follows:

  • Increase in glomerular capillary filtration coefficient Kf: This coefficient depends on the hydraulic conductivity and surface area of the glomerular capillaries. 
  • Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Conditions with urinary tract obstruction can lead to an increase in this pressure and a fall in GFR.
  • Decrease in glomerular colloid osmotic pressure: Accumulation of plasma proteins that are not filtered from the blood contributes to this pressure, and an increase reduces further filtration and GFR. It is directly proportional to the following factors: Arterial plasma colloid osmotic pressure.
  • Filtration fraction : An increase in filtration fraction concentrates the plasma proteins and raises the glomerular colloid osmotic pressure which in turn decreases the GFR.

Other options : 

Option A: Efferent Arteriole Dilation reduces the resistance to blood leaving the glomerulus. This leads to a decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. A reduction in hydrostatic pressure lowers the driving force for filtration, resulting in a decreased GFR.

Option B: Afferent Arteriole Constriction decreases blood flow into the glomerulus. This lowers the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. Lower pressure reduces the filtration rate across the glomerular capillary wall, leading to a decrease in GFR.

Option C: Increase in Glomerular Plasma Flow: If glomerular plasma flow increases but the efferent arteriole doesn't constrict, the extra blood flow is quickly carried away. This prevents a significant rise in the pressure inside the glomerular capillaries. As a result, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) doesn't significantly increase, because the necessary increase in filtration pressure doesn't occur.

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting GFR

Determinants

Physiological/Pathophysiological Causes

↓Kf (filtration coefficient)→ ↓GFR

Renal disease, diabetes mellitus, hypertension

↑PB → ↓GFR

Urinary tract obstruction (e.g., kidney stones)

↑πG → ↓GFR

↓ Renal blood flow increased plasma proteins

↓PG → ↓GFR

a) ↑afferent arteriolar resistance (RA )→ ↓PG

↑ Sympathetic activity, (e.g., norepinephrine, endothelin)

b) ↓systemic arterial pressure(AP )→ ↓PG

 Arterial pressure

c) ↓efferent arteriolar resistance (RE )→ ↓PG

↓ Angiotensin II (drugs that block angiotensin II formation)

PG : Glomerular hydrostatic pressure

πB : Colloid osmotic pressure of the proteins in Bowman’s capsule

PB : Hydrostatic pressure in Bowman’s capsule

πG : Colloid osmotic pressure of glomerular capillary plasma proteins

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the national vector-borne disease control program. Identify the disease caused by this vector.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese Encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Charateristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
EggsUsually 100-250. This stage lasts 1 – 2 days. Laid singly; boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star shaped clusters.
Larval stageThis stage lasts for 5 -7 days.

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Stripped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artifical collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and legs. 

 

 

  • Culex mosquito, they keep their bodies horizontal while feeding:

 

  • Anopheles mosquito as seen in the image below, they tend to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high:

 

  • Aedes mosquito (aegypti), as seen in the image below, their bodies are striped:

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the hanging mark is false?

choices.text: The most common position of the knot is under the chin
The gap in the hanging mark indicates the point of suspension
The hanging mark is situated above the thyroid cartilage
The mark dries to a parchment like consistency post-mortem

questions.solution:
The knot in a suicidal hanging is much less likely to be found under the chin than in other positions - behind the ear or at the occiput.

Hanging mark

  • The hanging mark almost never completely encircles the neck unless a slipknot is used.
  • In most instances the point of suspension is indicated by a gap in the skin mark.
  • This gap is usually seen at one or other side of the neck or at the centre of the back of the neck. Much less often it is under the chin.
  • The hanging mark is situated higher on the neck than in strangulation, usually being directly under the chin anteriorly, passing round beneath the jawbones and rising at the sides or back of the neck to the usual gap under the knot.
  • The mark may be abraded, brown and dried to a parchment-like consistency after death.
  • There may be a narrow red zone either above or below (or both sides) the ligature mark. This is not an indicator of vital reaction but is due to the displacement of blood laterally from under the zone of maximum pressure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old boxer was brought to the emergency following a blow to the abdomen. On examination, his vitals are normal. He has tenderness in the abdomen. Which among the following will be the best modality to assess injury to his abdominal organs?
questions.solution:
A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the best diagnostic modality (gold standard) for stable patients with blunt trauma to the abdomen.

It is a non-invasive and sensitive investigation. It can identify hemorrhage, intraabdominal as well as retroperitoneal organ injury. However, performing CECT is time-consuming (when compared to FAST) and therefore it can be used only in stable patients.

FAST ultrasound is a limited examination to look for intraperitoneal fluid or pericardial injury as a marker of the underlying injury. The best imaging modality for hemodynamically unstable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is FAST.

MRI is typically not the first-line imaging modality in the acute setting of abdominal trauma, as it may not be as readily available or as quick to perform as a CT scan. MRI may be considered in cases with a specific concern for soft tissue injuries.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles, as seen in the biopsy.

Image: Vacuolar myopathy in McArdle's disease

Features:

  • Poor exercise tolerance
  • Abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%)
  • Very low blood lactate after exercise

Image: Myophosphorylase enzyme histochemistry showing

(A) Normal muscle

(B) - McArdle's disease

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

questions.text: All of the following are signs and symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, except ______
questions.solution:
Vitamin A toxicity causes increased intracranial pressure.

The accumulation of vitamin A goes beyond the capacity of intracellular binding proteins producing hypervitaminosis.

Clinical features of hypervitaminosis A:

  • CNS: symptoms of raised intracranial pressure(pseudotumor cerebri) such as headache, nausea, vomiting, blurring of vision
  • Liver: hepatomegaly and hyperlipidemia
  • Bones: thickening of the long bones(bony exostosis), hypercalcemia, soft tissue calcification
  • Dermatological: dryness, exfoliative dermatitis, alopecia
  • Teratogenesis: Pregnant women should not ingest excessive quantities as it can cause congenital malformations in the developing fetus. Isotretinoin(13 cis retinoic acid) is a drug which is teratogenic and absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: From the following epidemic curve, identify the type of epidemic depicted.
questions.solution:
Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image.

In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time and they occur within one incubation period of the disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A young male who had a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his hip was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of posterior hip dislocation. In this condition, the leg will be in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. 

Posterior hip dislocation is the commonest type of hip dislocation accounting for about 80%  of the cases. It is commonly seen following dashboard injuries. The patient presents with flexion, adduction, and an internal rotation deformity.

Radiological findings include femoral head lying above and behind the acetabulum, femoral head appearing smaller than normal, lesser trochanter not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated and the femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen

Sciatic nerve injury is seen in 10-20 % of cases with posterior hip dislocation. It is usually a neuropraxia type of injury and resolves spontaneously. The femoral artery pulsation is usually felt against the neck of the femur. Due to the posterior dislocation of the hip joint, the femoral vessels fall backwards and the pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. This is called the vascular sign of Narath.

Anterior hip dislocation is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident. The affected limb in this condition will be abducted, externally rotated, and slightly flexed.

Note: Although, vascular injuries are seen in posterior dislocations as well, they are most likely with anterior dislocation. This is because of the femoral artery lying anterior to the head

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

questions.text: A child on beta 2 agonists for the treatment of bronchial asthma may exhibit all of the following except:
questions.solution:
β2 agonists are associated with hyperglycemia probably due to β2 receptor-mediated glycogenolysis and glucagon release.

Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists are

  • Muscle tremors: Direct effect on beta 2 receptors in skeletal muscles and due to hypokalemia
  • Tachycardia: Direct effect on cardiac beta 2 receptors, indirect sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on beta 2 receptors
  • Hypokalemia: Direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions
  • Hypoxemia
  • Hyperglycaemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Tolerance: Desensitization on long-term use

questions.text: You observed the following finding in a patient in the OPD. Which among the following conditions is least likely to cause this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely to cause digital clubbing.

Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Chronic interstitial pneumonitis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease (Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease)
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel
    • Cirrhosis - juvenile and biliary
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous fistula
    • Patent Ductus arteriosus
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism (Grave’s disease)
    • Thyroid acropachy
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)
  • Skin disease
    • Palmoplantar keratoderma
    • Fischer-Volavsek syndrome.
  • Malignancies
    • Thyroid cancer
    • Thymus cancer
    • Hodgkin disease
    • Disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia.

Note: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) does not cause clubbing. If clubbing is present in a patient with COPD, underlying lung cancer and bronchiectasis must be ruled out.

questions.text: A 34 year old construction worker with no comorbidities presents with exertional pain in both forearms and hands. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. On examination, brachial pulses are palpable but radial and ulnar pulses are feeble. Image  of his hand is shown. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmental lesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chances of success?
questions.solution:
This is a classical clinical scenario of thromboangiitis obliterans. There is no specific treatment except abstinence from tobacco.

Key points in the question:

  • Male < 40years
  • Smoker
  • Involvement of upper extremity
  • Raynauds phenomenon

Thromboangiitis Obliterans (Buerger’s disease):

  • An inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the distal upper and lower extremities.
  • Most common in men <40 years of age.
  • Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship to cigarette smoking in patients with this disorder.
  • MRA, CTA, and conventional arteriography show smooth, tapering segmental lesions in the distal vessels with collateral vessels at sites of vascular occlusion.
  • There is no specific treatment except abstention from tobacco.
  • The prognosis is worse in individuals who continue to smoke, but results are discouraging even in those who stop smoking.
  • Antibiotics may be useful.
  • Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful.
  • If these measures fail, amputation may be required.

No Smoking Day is observed every year on the second Wednesday of March. The aim of the campaign is to encourage people over the world to quit smoking. The main purpose of this day is to spread awareness about the harmful health effects of tobacco consumption through cigarette and other modes.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor arising from an undescended testis?
questions.solution:
The most common malignancy that occurs in an undescended testis is a seminoma (risk is 5–10 times).

An early orchidopexy is the management of choice because it helps in the early detection of these tumors in the testis as the testis is in the scrotum after the orchidopexy

The other complications that may develop as a result of the undescended testis can be remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion

E- Epididymorchitis

S- Sterility

T- Trauma (Increased risk)

I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)

S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a past medical history of generalized seizures controlled with phenytoin therapy. She had mild pallor on physical examination. Lab values reveal Hb -  9.8 g/dl, MCV - 106 fL, Platelets - 1,80,000/cu.mm, leukocytes - 7800/cu.mm. Which of the following supplementations could have prevented this anemia?
questions.solution:
This patient has mild megaloblastic anemia (high MCV), probably due to chronic phenytoin therapy. Some anti-epileptic drugs like phenytoin, phenobarbital can cause megaloblastic anemia by impairing absorption of folate in the small intestine. Folic acid supplementation can prevent this condition.

Related Pearl: Difference between B12 and Folic acid Deficiency

Laboratory Tests

Pernicious Anemia (B12 Deficiency)

Folic Acid Deficiency

Serum B12 level

Decreased

Normal

Serum folic acid level

Normal

Decreased

Serum LDH level

Increased

Normal

Achlorhydria

Present

Absent

Schilling Test

Positive

Negative

Methyl malonyl CoA in urine

Present

Absent

Neurological signs

Present

Absent

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the dermatology department with lesions over the skin as shown below.  On examination, the lesions were dry, scaly, and slightly shiny, with moderately diminished sensation. Which type of leprosy do these lesions indicate?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing of moderately hypoesthetic annular plaques with punched-out lesions is suggestive of the borderline-borderline (BB) type of leprosy.

BB is the most immunologically unstable type of the borderline spectrum. Patients in BB will shift towards lepromatous or tuberculoid types quickly. 

Skin lesions in BB are in the form of infiltrated papules, plaques, nodules. The characteristic lesions of BB leprosy are annular plaques with well-demarcated, punched-out inner margins and a sloping outer margin. They appear as large plaques with islands of clinically normal skin within the center, giving rise to Swiss cheese appearance. 

 

Inverted saucer lesions are raised lesions with ill-defined borders that are mainly seen in borderline lepromatous (BL) type of leprosy lesions as shown below.

Pure neuritic leprosy (PNL) is a rare variant of leprosy. It is characterized by isolated involvement of peripheral nerve trunks in the absence of skin lesions.

Patients with PNL present with nerve thickening pain, tenderness, and sensory-motor impairment. Sensory neuropathies like loss of heat and pain sensitivities are more predominant in PNL. they most commonly present with mononeuritis.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following tumors are best treated with radiotherapy?
questions.solution: Patients diagnosed with seminoma are best treated with radiotherapy, as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor.

questions.text: In which condition  is the X ray given below seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows folds that run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oseophageal lumen, which is called a feline esophagus and is seen in reflux esophagitis. 

Feline oesophagus is also known as oesophageal shiver, refers to the transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower oesophagus on a double contrast barium swallow. The appearance is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux and is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae with resultant shortening of the oesophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

Radiologic features: The folds are 1-2 mm thick and run horizontally around the entire circumference of the oseophageal lumen. The findings are transient, seen following reflux and not during swallowing. The appearance is confined to the distal two-thirds of the thoracic oesophagus.

It can also be seen in hiatus hernia and eosinophilic oesophagitis (wherein the folds will be permanent and be associated with strictures).

 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

questions.text: According to sigmund freud in the interpretation of dreams, which of the following terms refers to the representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected with the idea or object being represented?
questions.solution:
Symbolism refers to the representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected with the idea or object being represented.

According to the Interpretation of dreams written by sigmund freud, dreams represent unconscious wishes or thoughts which are not accepted by the conscious mind. They manifest through the following mechanisms:

  • Symbolism: Representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected. 
  • Displacement: Transfer of mental energy from one object to a substitute or symbolic representation of the object. 
  • Condensation: Mechanism by which multiple unconscious wishes combine into a single image. Converse to it is called irradiation or diffusion, where, one unconscious wish gets distributed into multiple images. 
  • Projection: Attributing one’s own unacknowledged feelings to others. 
  • Secondary elaboration: Process by which the ego organizes illogical, bizarre and absurd images into a more coherent form in dreams. 

 

Related Pearl: Contributions by Sigmund Freud

Contributions of Sigmund Freud to the field of psychiatry

  • Free association
  • Interpretation of dreams
  • Psychoanalysis
  • Psycho-sexual development 
  • Psychodynamic theory 
  • Topographic theory of the mind-unconscious, preconscious, conscious
  • Structural theory of mind- id, ego, superego
  • Cocaine in psychiatry

questions.text: You are performing intrauterine insemination during the ovulatory period in a patient with infertility. When will you expect implantation to occur?
questions.solution:
The fertilized ovum implants by 6–7 days in the uterine cavity.

Implantation involves: 

  •  Apposition: Blastocyst starts to establish contact with the uterine wall.
  •  Adhesion: Increase in the physical interaction between the blastocyst and the uterine epithelium.
  •  Invasion: Syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts penetrate and invade the endometrium.

Prior to implantation, the endometrium is primed with estrogen and progesterone from the corpus luteum. This uterine receptivity is maximal from the 20th - 24th days of the endometrial cycle. Failure of embryo transfer during this time period may result in repeated implantation failure in IVF patients. 

Adherence of the blastocyst to the uterine cavity is a result of interaction between the cell-surface receptors at the implantation site and the blastocyst receptors. 

Related Pearl: Timeline of Various Events Occurring during the Pre-embryonic Phase Development (1st two weeks)

S.No.

Time after Fertilization

Event

1.

< 24 hrs

Zygote is formed; cleavage begins immediately

2.

2–3 days

5–8 cell stage

3.

3–4 days

Stage of compaction and formation of morula with 16 cells

4.

4–5 days

Formation of blastocyst

5.

5–6 days

Zona pellucida disappears

6.

6–7 days

Implantation of the blastocyst

7.

8 days

Bilaminar disc formation

8.

12 days

Formation of extraembryonic mesoderm

questions.text: A flow-volume loop is given below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given flow-volume loop, the expiratory and inspiratory curves are flattened which is characteristic of fixed upper airway obstruction i.e. tracheal stenosis in this case.

Vocal cord paralysis causes a variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction in which only the inspiratory curve would be flattened.

Note : a normal flow-volume loop begins on the X-axis (Volume axis): at the start of the test both flow and volume are equal to zero. After the starting point the curve rapidly mounts to a peak: Peak (Expiratory) Flow.

Then, the PEF the curve descends (=the flow decreases) as more air is expired. A normal, non-pathological F/V loop will descend in a straight or a convex line from top (PEF) to bottom (FVC).

The forced inspiration that follows the forced expiration has roughly the same morphology, but the PIF (Peak Inspiratory Flow) is not as distinct as PEF.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a fibrous joint?
questions.solution:
Symphysis is not a fibrous joint, but a secondary cartilaginous joint.

Structurally, joints are classified as fibrous joints, cartilaginous joints, and synovial joints (see the table). Sutures, syndesmosis, and gomphosis are fibrous joints. Symphysis and synchondrosis are types of cartilaginous joints. 

Structural classification of joints
Type  Subtypes
Fibrous joints
  • Sutures
  • Syndesmosis
  • Gomphosis
Cartilaginous joints
  • Primary cartilaginous joints (or synchondrosis)
  • Secondary cartilaginous joints (or symphysis)
 Synovial joints
  • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
  • Sellar or saddle joints
  • Condylar or bicondylar joints
  • Ellipsoid joints
  • Hinge joints
  • Pivot or trochoid joints
  • Plane joints

questions.text: The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is  ________.

choices.text: Umbilical artery → inferior vena cava → ductus venosus → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical artery → superior vena cava → right atrium → ductus arteriosus → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus arteriosus → superior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium

questions.solution:
The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior venacava → right atrium → left atrium.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
A patient who has had exposure to HBV will have Anti HBc antibodies even when he has moved into the chronic or recurrent stages. IgM anti-HBc reappears during acute recurrences while IgG Anti HBc is found in chronic states. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - - - IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - + IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG -

Post-vaccination

 - + - - - -

questions.text: This is the partograph of a primigravida in labor. What is the next line of management?

choices.text: Induction of labor by mechanical methods

questions.solution:
Cesarean section is the next line of management as the plotting on the above partograph has crossed the action line.

Partograph is analysed using alert and action lines. When the graph crosses the action line, active intervention should be initiated.

Labor is divided into a latent phase (average of 8 hrs in primi and 6 hrs in multigravida) and an active phase.

Clinically the active phase starts at ≥6 cm dilatation, and progress should be no slower than 1 cm/hr.

A 4-hour wait is recommended before intervention when the active phase is slow.

questions.text: Modified Mallampati grading is used in the assessment of _______.
questions.solution:
The Modified Mallampati classification is used in the assessment of difficult airway.

Modified Mallampati grading:

  • Class 0: Ability to see any part of the epiglottis upon mouth opening and tongue protrusion
  • Class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula, pillars visible
  • Class II: Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible
  • Class III: Soft palate, base of uvula visible
  • Class IV: Soft palate not visible at all

Test: The assessment is performed with the patient sitting up straight, mouth open and tongue maximally protruded, without speaking or saying “ahh.”

Classes 3 and 4 are difficult intubation situations.

Percentage of glottic opening (POGO score) and Cormack–Lehane (CL) classification is broadly used to describe laryngeal view during direct laryngoscopy.

Seshagiri Rao Mallampati (1941 – ) is an Indian-origin American anesthesiologist. The ‘original’ Mallampati scoring system had only three stages and was published in 1985.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding serous otitis media?

choices.text: Adenoid hypertrophy is the most common cause in children causing bilateral serous otitis media
Tumors of nasopharynx is most common cause in adults causing unilateral serous otitis media

questions.solution:
All the given statements are true.

Serous otitis media: 

The fluid is nearly sterile and the causes are :

Malfunctioning of eustachian tube:

  • Adenoid hyperplasia in children.
  • Benign and malignant tumors of nasopharynx. This cause should always be excluded in unilateral serous otitis media in an adult.

Other causes include

  • Interference with ET opening like in cleft lip and cleft palate and enlarged tonsils
  • Otitic barotrauma
  • Increased middle ear secretions like in an allergy.
  • Persistent effusion of ASOM due to inadequate treatment dose or duration

questions.text: Identify the hysterosalpingogram.
questions.solution:
The image shows normal hysterosalpingogram (HSG).

Note both fallopian tubes are patent with spill into peritoneal cavity.

Hysterosalpingogram: Filling defects:

Above HSG showing bilateral dilated Fallopian tubes with no free spill suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx

Above HSG showing unicornuate uterus

Above HSG showing bicornuate uterus/septate uterus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of diarrhea and abdominal pain since 6 months comes to the clinic with worsening abdominal pain. Endoscopy is performed. All of the following endoscopic findings are associated with the condition shown in the image below except:
questions.solution:
The endoscopic image showing cobblestone appearance along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease. Fine granular mucosa is seen in ulcerative colitis.

Endoscopic findings in Crohn's disease include:

  • Aphthous ulcers- Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers- Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance- Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas.

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

 

  Crohn's disease Ulcerative colitis

Skip lesions; can affect any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus, the rectum is usually spared

Mainly affects colon and rectum in a continuous manner.

Anus is spared

questions.text: Non-sense mutation is seen in _____________.
questions.solution:
Non-sense mutation is seen in β0 thalassemia.

A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. The point mutations within the coding sequences of the DNA (i.e., the region of the DNA that  codes for proteins) are of two types:

  1. Missense mutations
  2. Non-sense mutations

1. Missense mutations: These mutations may involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases and lead to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. Because these mutations alter the meaning of the sequence of the encoded protein, they are often referred to as missense mutations.                                                                                                                                                                            Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:

a) Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change in the function of the protein.

b) Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one. An example of this type of mutation is sickle-cell anemia, which is characterized by point mutation affecting the β-globin chain of the hemoglobin, where the nucleotide triplet CTC (or GAG in mRNA), which encodes glutamic acid, is changed to CAC (or GUG in mRNA), which encodes valine.

2. Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of β-globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called β0 thalassemia.

The illustration below shows various types of point mutations:

Other options:

  • Option b: The α-thalassemias are caused by inherited deletions that result in the reduced or absent synthesis of α-globin chains.
  • Option c: Sickle-cell anemia is an example of non-conservative missense mutation.
  • Option d: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.
